definitions.definition: To cause ( rays of light , etc) to converge at a single point.
To adjust (a lens , an optical instrument) in order to position an image with respect to the focal plane .
examples: You'll need to focus the microscope carefully in order to capture the full detail of this surface.

definitions.definition: To adjust itself or be adjusted such that light from a scene converges appropriately to create a clear image.
examples: I can't get the lens to focus .
The camera focuses automatically on the subject's eyes.
definitions.label_groups: intransitive , optics , of a lens, optical instrument, etc.

definitions.definition: To direct attention, effort, or energy to a particular audience or task.
examples: The president focused her remarks on the newcomers.
If you're going to beat your competitors, you need to focus .

definitions.definition: To concentrate one's attention on something; to have as one's central point of interest, concern, etc.
examples: I have to focus on my work.
definitions.label_groups: intransitive , followed by on or upon

definitions.definition: To transfer the input focus to (a visual element), so that it receives subsequent input.
examples: The text box won't receive the user's keystrokes unless you explicitly focus it.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To cause ( rays of light , etc) to converge at a single point.
secondary_definitions: ( transitive , optics ) To adjust (a lens , an optical instrument) in order to position an image with respect to the focal plane .
( intransitive , optics , of a lens, optical instrument, etc. ) To adjust itself or be adjusted such that light from a scene converges appropriately to create a clear image.
( transitive ) To direct attention, effort, or energy to a particular audience or task.
( intransitive , followed by on or upon ) To concentrate one's attention on something; to have as one's central point of interest, concern, etc.
( computing , graphical user interface , transitive ) To transfer the input focus to (a visual element), so that it receives subsequent input.
( accounting , formerly ) To aggregate figures of accounts.
